Scathing and hilarious takedown of a frontman for the rich and powerful

Celebrity philanthropy comes in many guises, but no single figure better encapsulates its delusions, pretensions and wrongheadedness than U2Ã¢â‚¬â„¢s iconic frontman, BonoÃ¢â‚¬â€a fact neither sunglasses nor leather pants can hide. More than a mere philanthropistÃ¢â‚¬â€indeed, he is said to lag behind some peers when it comes to parting with his own moneyÃ¢â‚¬â€Bono is better described as an advocate, one who has become an unwitting symbol of a complacent wealthy Western elite.

The Frontman shows how Bono defended U2's partial move to Amsterdam, avoiding Irish taxes; his paternalistic advocacy of neoliberal solutions in Africa; his multinational business interests; and his hobnobbing with Paul Wolfowitz and shock-doctrine economist Jeffrey Sachs. Carefully dissecting the rhetoric and actions of Bono the political operator, The Frontman argues that he is an ambassador for imperial exploitation, a man who has turned his attention to a world of savage injustice, inequality and exploitationÃ¢â‚¬â€and helped make it worse.


By Harry Browne
Published by Verso in 2013
EPUB, Retail, 192 pages, English
